text: I started playing the piano when I was 2
and the viola when I was 3 and actually
I started to compose when I was 4 so
writing things down on paper you just
found that the music was coming to you
yes I didn't even know that it was
called composing then I just sit at the
piano and play the ideas I hide in my
head well let's hear one of them which
actually you came up with this when you
were 9 and it's what you'll be playing
at the Henley festival tomorrow it's
lovely to what actually to watch you
listening to that how do you feel when
you hear that well when I was when when
I was playing with her with the
orchestra then in the beginning and I
thought that they were a little bit
suspicious you know they looked as if
you know who's this little girl you know
but then when I turned to them and I
start I take my cadenza but I think
they've changed their minds immediately
and yes I've read that you when you're
composing and I don't if you still do I
mean you've grown up a bit since 9:00
that you compose when you're skipping
yes I still do that I have an escape in
rope which actually I don't skip with it
I just wave it around and I tell stories
in my head and then sometimes a melody
just pops into my head and so that's how
I get my tunes or sometimes when I'm
just waking up I get them or I'm just
falling asleep or watching the middle of
the night when I am asleep but getting
the tunes for me actually that's the
easy bit but then then having to sit
down and developing it into proper
pieces and combining it with other
melodies in a coherent way and polishing
it that's a really difficult bit for me
[Applause]
of course you are being likened to
Mozart how do you feel about that well
and I actually think that if I was again
just him a little Mozart and it would be
a bit boring because I would just
worried exactly what Mozart had written
before I think I would prefer to be a
little Alma certainly are that
